Article.ArticleTitle: Investigate on the Mechanism of HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> Interface Passivation Based on Low-Temperature Ozone Oxidation and Si-Cap Methods.

AbstractText: The interface passivation of the HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> stack is systematically investigated based on low-temperature ozone oxidation and Si-cap methods. Compared with the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> stack, the dispersive feature and interface state density (D<sub>it</sub>) of the HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> stack MOS (Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor) capacitor under ozone direct oxidation (pre-O sample) increases obviously. This is because the tiny amounts of GeO<sub>x</sub> in the formed interlayer (IL) oxide layer are more likely to diffuse into HfO<sub>2</sub> and cause the HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> interface to deteriorate. Moreover, a post-HfO<sub>2</sub>-deposition (post-O) ozone indirect oxidation is proposed for the HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> stack; it is found that compared with pre-O sample, the D<sub>it</sub> of the post-O sample decreases by about 50% due to less GeO<sub>x</sub> available in the IL layer. This is because the amount of oxygen atoms reaching the interface of HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> decreases and the thickness of IL in the post-O sample also decreases. To further reduce the D<sub>it</sub> of the HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> interface, a Si-cap passivation with the optimal thickness of 1 nm is developed and an excellent HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> interface with D<sub>it</sub> of 1.53 × 10<sup>11</sup> eV<sup>-1</sup>cm<sup>-2</sup> @ E-E<sub>v</sub> = 0.36 eV is attained. After detailed analysis of the chemical structure of the HfO<sub>2</sub>/IL/Si-cap/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), it is confirmed that the excellent HfO<sub>2</sub>/Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> interface is realized by preventing the formation of Hf-silicate/Hf-germanate and Si oxide originating from the reaction between HfO<sub>2</sub> and Si<sub>0.7</sub>Ge<sub>0.3</sub> substrate.
